questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'She teaches mathematics.'
options: Mathematics is taught by her
Mathematics was taught by her
Mathematics is teaching by her
Mathematics teaches by her
questions.explanation: Simple Present Active 'teaches' converts to 'is taught' in passive. Formula: Object + is/are + V3 + by + Subject.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'Ram is writing a letter.'
options: A letter is written by Ram
A letter is being written by Ram
A letter was being written by Ram
A letter has been written by Ram
questions.explanation: Present Continuous Active converts to 'is/are + being + V3' in passive. So 'is writing' becomes 'is being written'.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'They have completed the work.'
options: The work is completed by them
The work was completed by them
The work has been completed by them
The work had been completed by them
questions.explanation: Present Perfect Active 'have completed' converts to 'has/have + been + V3' in passive.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'They built this house in 1990.'
options: This house is built by them in 1990
This house was built by them in 1990
This house has been built by them in 1990
This house was being built by them in 1990
questions.explanation: Simple Past Active 'built' (V2) converts to 'was/were + V3' in passive. The time marker '1990' indicates simple past.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'She was teaching English.'
options: English is being taught by her
English was taught by her
English was being taught by her
English has been taught by her
questions.explanation: Past Continuous Active 'was teaching' converts to 'was/were + being + V3' in passive.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'He had finished his homework.'
options: His homework has been finished by him
His homework was finished by him
His homework had been finished by him
His homework is finished by him
questions.explanation: Past Perfect Active 'had finished' converts to 'had + been + V3' in passive.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'They will play cricket tomorrow.'
options: Cricket is played by them tomorrow
Cricket will be played by them tomorrow
Cricket was played by them tomorrow
Cricket has been played by them tomorrow
questions.explanation: Simple Future Active 'will play' converts to 'will + be + V3' in passive.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'She will have completed the project by Monday.'
options: The project will be completed by her by Monday
The project will have been completed by her by Monday
The project has been completed by her by Monday
The project was completed by her by Monday
questions.explanation: Future Perfect Active 'will have completed' converts to 'will + have + been + V3' in passive.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'You should complete this work today.'
options: This work should complete by you today
This work should be completed by you today
This work should completed by you today
This work should being completed by you today
questions.explanation: With modal verbs, use: Modal + be + V3. So 'should complete' becomes 'should be completed'.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'He can solve this problem.'
options: This problem can be solved by him
This problem can solved by him
This problem can be solve by him
This problem could be solved by him
questions.explanation: Modal 'can' in passive becomes 'can + be + V3'. So 'can solve' becomes 'can be solved'.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'We must finish this task.'
options: This task must be finished by us
This task must finished by us
This task must be finish by us
This task must being finished by us
questions.explanation: Modal 'must' in passive becomes 'must + be + V3'. So 'must finish' becomes 'must be finished'.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'Close the door.' (Imperative)
options: The door is closed
Let the door be closed
The door was closed
The door should be closed
questions.explanation: Imperative sentences in passive use 'Let + Object + be + V3'. So 'Close the door' becomes 'Let the door be closed'.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'He gave me a book.'
options: I was given a book by him
A book was given by him
A book is given to me by him
I am given a book by him
questions.explanation: In sentences with two objects, the person usually becomes the subject in passive. 'Me' becomes 'I' (subject form).

questions.questionText: Convert to active voice: 'The letter was written by Sita.'
options: Sita writes the letter
Sita wrote the letter
Sita is writing the letter
Sita has written the letter
questions.explanation: Passive 'was written' (Simple Past) converts to Simple Past Active 'wrote'. The agent 'by Sita' becomes the subject.

questions.questionText: Convert to active voice: 'English is spoken here.'
options: They speak English here
They spoke English here
They are speaking English here
They have spoken English here
questions.explanation: Passive 'is spoken' (Simple Present) converts to Simple Present Active 'speak'. When agent is not mentioned, we use 'they/people'.

questions.questionText: Identify the voice: 'The book is being read by students.'
options: Active Voice
Passive Voice
Both
Neither
questions.explanation: This is Passive Voice because: (1) Subject 'book' receives action, (2) Uses 'is being + V3', (3) Has 'by + agent'.

questions.questionText: Which sentence CANNOT be converted to passive voice?
options: She sings a song
He sleeps at night
They build houses
We eat food
questions.explanation: 'He sleeps' is an intransitive verb with no object, so it cannot be converted to passive. All others have objects and can be passive.

questions.questionText: Convert to passive voice: 'Did you complete the assignment?'
options: Was the assignment completed by you?
Is the assignment completed by you?
Has the assignment been completed by you?
Will the assignment be completed by you?
questions.explanation: Question in Simple Past 'Did...complete' converts to 'Was/Were + Object + V3 + by + Subject?'
